clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Wheelchair Skills Training for Caregivers of Manual Wheelchair Users
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Wheelchair Skills Training for Caregivers of Manual Wheelchair Users: a Randomized Waitlist-controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Although there is strong evidence to support the role of wheelchair skills training for wheelchair users when receiving a new wheelchair, there has never been a randomized controlled study looking at the effectiveness of training the caregivers. The main purpose of this study is to test if providing wheelchair skills training to caregivers of new manual wheelchair users enhances caregiver-assisted wheelchair skills ability and confidence in comparison to a control group of participants who are receiving usual care while on a wait list for wheelchair skills training. The investigators will also study whether the benefits of training are still seen at a 6-week follow-up and assess the health-economic impact of caregiver training.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A single-blind randomized waitlist-controlled trial. Each participant in the study consists of a caregiver and wheelchair user dyad. 1 dyad = 1 manual wheelchair user + his/her caregiver. Those randomized to waitlist control group will receive the intervention after 5 weeks.
study_design_info.masking_description: This is a single-blind study. The outcomes assessor and the wheelchair skills trainer will be blind to group allocation. Because of the nature of the study, it will not be possible to blind participants.

primary_outcome.measure: Wheelchair Skills Test Questionnaire - Capacity version
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported ability to perform 33 wheelchair skills. Score ranges from 0-100%, with 0 indicating a poor outcome (not able to do any wheelchair skills and 100% indicating being able to do all the skills).

primary_outcome.measure: Wheelchair Skills Test Questionnaire - Confidence version
primary_outcome.description: Self-reported confidence in performing 33 wheelchair skills. Score ranges from 0 - 100%, with 0 indicating a poor outcome (no confidence in doing any wheelchair skills and 100% indicating full confidence in doing all wheelchair skills).

secondary_outcome.description: Participants will be asked a few questions on the experience of receiving wheelchair skills training

secondary_outcome.measure: Effectiveness of early versus delayed training on wheelchair skills capacity
secondary_outcome.description: Self-reported ability to perform 33 wheelchair skills. Score ranges from 0-100%, with 0 indicating a poor outcome (not able to do any wheelchair skills and 100% indicating being able to do all the skills).

secondary_outcome.measure: Effectiveness of early versus delayed training on wheelchair skills confidence
secondary_outcome.description: Self-reported confidence in performing 33 wheelchair skills. Score ranges from 0 - 100%, with 0 indicating a poor outcome (no confidence in doing any wheelchair skills and 100% indicating full confidence in doing all wheelchair skills).

arm_group.description: The wheelchair user and caregiver will be trained together on wheelchair skills. Training will be individualized dependent on initial results of wheelchair skills test and identified individual goals and will occur about a week after the initial data collection session.

The wheelchair user and caregiver will receive "usual care", which may include wheelchair skills training for both wheelchair users and caregivers( but which often does not do so to an adequate extent) for 5 weeks. At the end of 5 weeks, the wheelchair user and caregiver will be trained together on wheelchairs skills similar to the protocol for the experimental group.

intervention.description: The wheelchair user and caregiver will be trained together on wheelchair skills, using the principles of the Wheelchair Skills Training Program, as outlined in the Wheelchair Skills Program Manual. Each training session will be with a trainer-to-dyad ratio of 1:1 1 dyad = 1 manual wheelchair user + his/her caregiver. Training will continue until the goals have been met and retained (for at least one subsequent session), using up to 4 training sessions that will each last 30-60 minutes at intervals of 1-10 days. Prior to the first training session, the trainer will be provided with the wheelchair skills test questionnaire results from the assessment immediately preceding training to provide him/her time to individualize the training session.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for caregiver and wheelchair user dyad
- be â‰¥ 18 years of age
- able to communicate in English
- live within 50 km of the testing and training facility
- be willing to participate (as evidenced by the provision of informed consent and completion of the baseline [T1] assessment)
- be able to set regularly scheduled times for the study visits when both the caregiver and wheelchair user will be present
Exclusion Criteria for caregiver and wheelchair user dyad :
- have unstable medical conditions (e.g. angina, seizures) that might make the use of a manual wheelchair dangerous
- emotional problems (e.g. severe anxiety, depression) that might make participation unsafe or unpleasant
Inclusion Criteria for wheelchair user
- a person who is using a manual wheelchair for the first time during this admission (which may include the acute-care site from which he/she has been transferred)
- be expected to continue to use a manual wheelchair for at least 6 hours per week for the next 3 months
- requires no more than minimal assistance for communication and auditory comprehension
Inclusion Criteria for caregiver of wheelchair user
-must be an unpaid caregiver (e.g. a family member or friend) who spends an average total of at least 2 hours per week with the manual wheelchair user that includes manual wheelchair mobility.
